ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TALKS ON GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE


    1. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what are the probable negative consequences for Singapore if the talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade fail to reach a successful conclusion on l5th December l993; and (b) what are the Government's contingency plans.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Uruguay Round negotiations are not going smoothly. As the deadline of 15th

Column: 1190

December approaches, there is a special effort underway to resolve the more contentious points. It is therefore likely that the major players will come to some compromise at the last minute. The compromise may result in a smaller package than what is presently being negotiated. A smaller package is better than a complete failure provided that the areas that are excised from the final agreement do not tilt the balance of interests between the developed and developing countries.

    Sir, it s not possible to predict with certainty the outcome of a failure. Certain dangers are clear. The present GATT regime has been eroded by protective measures taken by countries such as arbitrary Anti-Dumping measures, voluntary export restraints, and other unilateral actions. Failure to conclude the Round is likely to accelerate this trend and protectionist sentiments may become dominant in countries which are having difficulty competing against imports. Protectionist measures taken by one country may lead to counter protectionist measures by others. Free trade would come under strong threat, negating the achievements made by GATT in the past decades.

    A spiralling series of protectionist moves with consequent reduction in international trade cannot go on forever. At some point, countries will realise, after paying the price, that a multi-lateral trading system with free flow of goods and services is the only option for economic growth. While we await such a change, we must continue to be nimble, adapt to new circumstances, and use our resources to make ourselves more competitive. We must seek new opportunities and niches in a more protectionist regional and international market.

    To the extent that we can, we should work with countries that have a common interest, to come together and form economic groupings targeted at trade liberalisation. We have started this process within ASEAN under the AFTA Scheme. Economic linkages in groupings

Column: 1191

like APEC are also growing in significance. We should continue to explore various forms of tie-ups and linkages to expand business opportunities when the time is right. Such groupings cannot replace a global trading system like GATT. But they can give us some respite until we move to an open global free trade system.

    In essence, we will continue to maintain our free trade policy and encourage our neighbours to do so. We shall continue to introduce policies and invest in those areas that will keep Singapore competitive. We will also join economic groupings that aim at promoting free flow of trade and investment.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, because we are a free port, ie, we practise free trade, is it difficult for us to negotiate bilateral arrangements as we have nothing more to offer when protectionist blocs start coming up?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, even if we have a series of duties, our market is not that significant that we can expect to negotiate substantial benefits for ourselves on a bilateral basis. But I think we must concentrate on working with countries which do realise the advantage of a free global system and try and help them in GATT, or if GATT fails, in other negotiations, to come together to create a more liberal system.

    Sir, it is a bit too early to talk and elaborate on what will happen if GATT fails because there are fairly good indications that it will succeed. As I said, it might be a smaller package than originally envisaged, but still it is better than a complete failure.

NATIONAL SERVICEMEN
(Disruption of service for further studies)


    2. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for Defence what is the rationale of requiring national servicemen, whose service was disrupted for further studies, to complete their service in a continuous period lasting no less than six months, where applicable.

Column: 1192



     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Matthias Yao Chih) (for the Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, disruption for further studies is granted to national servicemen who have 2 1/2 years of full-time liability. Ideally, such servicemen should remain in the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) for the whole 2 1/2 years to complete all the required training courses and exercises. However, disruption is allowed to this group after they have served a minimum required period so that they need not start their further studies later than those who have only two years to serve.

    Disruption is a postponement of full-time training. It is not the end of full-time national service. The balance period should be effectively used to prepare the servicemen for an operational role. As far as possible, he will be deployed to a unit which is undergoing the type of training he has missed during his disruption. All national servicemen must undergo the key phases of full-time training and be operationally ready by the time they finish national service. To achieve this, the period they spend for training after disruption has to be long enough to enable them to complete the phases they have missed. It would be wasteful and counter-productive for the serviceman if he were to return to the SAF for short spells just so that he can complete his 2 1/2 years service without receiving the appropriate training.

    Furthermore, national servicemen who are disrupted for further studies are likely to hold the rank of officer or junior commander. They must be fully trained to take on leadership roles in their reservist units. Those who miss the prescribed higher level courses before they finish national service will have to be sent for such courses during the remaining period. There will be little or no opportunity for them to take such courses when they have become reservists, as the length of most of the courses at this level is greater than the normal reservist call-up period.

    To ensure proper deployment and minimum waste of the servicemen's time, the SAF therefore requires that the remaining service be served in one

Column: 1193

continuous period. Most servicemen have no problems over this requirement. 83% of disrupted servicemen have a balance period of only two months or less, and can complete their service during their first university vacations. The rest, who have longer balance periods, would have missed substantial portions of their training. They should return to follow the full training syllabus appropriate to their ranks and vocation in the same manner as their counterparts who are not disrupted.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, what are the specific reasons for not allowing overseas medical students to do their national service during their vacations, a practice which was formerly permissible?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, students who go for overseas study are disrupted for the full duration of their courses. During their vacations when they come back, which is no more than 2-3 months, they can complete their service during that time. This can be considered. However, their disruption is for the full 3-4 years anyway. It is not the same as the disruption that is applicable to local students.

Column: 1193

NATIONAL SERVICE FOR GIRLS


    3. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Defence whether he will now consider extending national service, in suitable forms, to girls.

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih (for the Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, in spite of the declining birth rate in the sixties and seventies, the Ministry of Defence (MINDEF) has been able to cope with the manpower shortage through measures such as raising the productivity of the SAF, upgrading the management systems, and extensive computerisation of administration and operations. We have increased our effectiveness to make up for the reduction in numbers. Therefore, there is no defence need, for the foreseeable future, for MINDEF to extend national service to girls. Rather than being helpful to MINDEF, such a measure would only

Column: 1194

place a further strain to our labour shortage and adversely affect our economy.

    Instead of introducing national service for all females, MINDEF recruits the required number of females to join the SAF voluntarily by offering competitive market rates. There are currently more than 4,000 females working in the SAF. Over the years, the deployment of women in non-combat positions in the SAF has released more men to take on combat postings, thus ensuring that our defence deterrence and operational readiness is not compromised.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, while accepting Mr Matthias Yao's explanation, would it be a matter of fair treatment for both the male and female, as we have a lot of women leaders asking for fair treatment, and I have a daughter who says she does not mind serving national service?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, activating the Enlistment Act to conscript our citizens for military service is a rather serious business and we would not freely use such an instrument to solve our manpower shortage. If any Member's daughter wishes to enlist, there are many positions available to women in the SAF and we pay competitive market rates for such jobs.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: The point is equal treatment. As we are talking about equal treatment these days, does he not feel that the treatment is not equal if we differentiate the sexes?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, indeed it is not equal. We demand from our men a period of national service as well as a reservist liability. To call up women to do the same is equal treatment, but perhaps it is not necessary at this time.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary agree that there could never be equal treatment for men and women?

     Mr Matthias Yao Chih: Sir, MINDEF is not in a position to determine whether in this world there is fair or unfair treatment for women and men. In the same way that

Column: 1195

all refuse truck drivers are men, it does not mean that we must have an equal proportion who are women.

Column: 1195

VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN IN SINGAPORE


    4. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Home Affairs what is the position of violence against women in Singapore.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, crimes of violence against women can be grouped into two categories, namely, sexual offences and other offences.

    Sexual offences committed are mostly rape and outraging of modesty. For rape, in 1991, there were 74 cases and in 1992 there were 80 cases, the figures for both years were lower than 1990 when there were 111 cases. Therefore, the numbers have come down. In the first 10 months of this year, there were 69 reported cases.

    Sir, the number of outraging of modesty cases rose from 716 in 1990 to 774 in 1992. However, Police point out that one factor explaining the increased figures is that more women are now prepared to come forward and report such offences due to changes in public attitude towards such crimes and the easy access to Neighbourhood Police Posts. Since the Member has asked specifically about violence, she would be assured to know that only about 20% of these outrage of modesty cases involved violence.

    Sir, as for non-sexual offences, women were victims in about 15% (seven victims) of the murder cases in the first 10 months of 1993. For offences of voluntarily causing grievous hurt, females constituted 20% of the victims (51 victims) during the same period.

    Sir, the statistics therefore suggest that the situation of violence against women in Singapore is well under control and has not changed significantly in recent years. The Police will continue to monitor the situation.

Column: 1196

APPLICATION FOR HDB RENTAL FLATS
(Increase in income ceiling)


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for National Development what is the rationale for setting the household income ceiling of $800 for eligibility to apply for Housing and Development Board rental flats; and whether he will consider increasing the ceiling to $1,200.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's aim is to encourage as many Singaporeans as possible to own their flats, so that they can have a stake in the country. Thus, subsidised rental accommodation is limited to those households in the lower income group, with monthly incomes not exceeding $800, who genuinely cannot afford to purchase their own flats.

    Households with incomes of more than $800 should be able to afford the monthly instalments for a new 4-room `budget' HDB flat in New Towns like Choa Chu Kang, Jurong West and Woodlands. The average prices of the 4-room `budget' flats in these New Towns range from $70,000 to $83,000. At such prices, the corresponding monthly instalments payable range from $255 to $300, and can be serviced entirely from the CPF contributions of households with incomes of as low as $850.

    Those who find difficulty buying an HDB flat are provided with assistance under HDB's Low Income Incentive Scheme, whereby families with household incomes of $1,000 or less, buying a 4-room Simplified or smaller flat, are given a loan of up to 95% (instead of the usual 80%) of the selling price of the flat, and need only pay a downpayment of 5%.

    My Ministry therefore does not see the need to revise the $800 income ceiling for rental flats for the time being.

Column: 1196

GOVERNMENT/RESTRUCTURED HOSPITALS AND OUTPATIENT CLINICS
(Pricing policy of medicines)


    6. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the pricing policy of

Column: 1197

medicines prescribed in all Government and restructured hospitals and outpatient clinics; and (b) whether he will consider introducing controls on the profits allowed on the sale of medicines by doctors, clinics, hospitals and pharmacies.

     The Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, Government and restructured hospitals and specialist outpatient clinics (SOCs) provide standard and some non-standard drugs. Standard drugs prescribed to Class B2 and C patients are charged at subsidised rates while those for Class A and B1 patients are charged at cost. Over time, we will rationalise these rates to match the subsidy targets for the different class wards. For non-standard drugs, the policy is to recover the cost from all classes of patients. However, Class B2 and C patients who are prescribed non-standard drugs and have difficulty paying may apply for remission of these charges, as at present.

    On average, the cost of drugs constitutes less than 10% of a hospital bill.

    The Ministry has no plan to introduce controls on the pricing of medicine in clinics, hospitals and pharmacies in the private sector. Presently, patients in the private sector have a choice of getting the medicines from the doctors' clinics or to request for a prescription to buy the drugs from private pharmacies.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, from the Minister of State's answer, I do not feel that you are pricing the medicine according to cost. Dr Moses Yu called me and said they actually price according to cost, a multiple of a few times. His answer was that cheap medicine, ie, medicines costing by the cents, you multiply it, and it could be a five to seven times profit. But there are certain medicines that they price below cost. So it could be an averaging that you are doing. I do not know.

     Mr Speaker: What is your question?

     Mr Chia Shi Teck: Sir, the question is that the answer I got from the doctor to the question which I asked the last time, and the Minister of State's answer do not

Column: 1198

seem to tally. I put in the question because I thought that it has a policy in pricing and that the cheaper drugs are priced at a higher profit, and the expensive drugs are priced at a subsidy. Is that the way you price it? I do not know.

     Dr Aline Wong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Chia's question is on the general pricing policy. It is not about specific ways in which drugs are priced. I do remember that the last time he spoke on the White Paper, he raised this question about some drugs being more expensive. But I wish he had also checked his facts. Dr Moses Yu also informed me that for all the expensive drugs - and I have checked the prices - the charges at Government and restructured hospitals and SOCs are cheaper than private pharmacies.

    If you are referring to certain drugs which constitute a very small proportion of our Standard Drugs List which are priced slightly higher than the cost - our practice is to charge $1 per item per week, up to a maximum of $4 per week - out of the nearly 500 items of standard drugs, less than 10% cost less. But you have to add the administrative cost for dispensing and procuring the drugs. So for administrative convenience, less than 10% of the standard drugs dispensed at outpatient clinics can be slightly higher than the cost. But these average out with those drugs charged below cost.

CERTIFICATES OF ENTITLEMENT
(Increase in tender prices)


    7. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Communications whether he intends to take any action in regard to the unabated increase in the tender prices of Certificates of Entitlement.

     The Minister of State for Communications (Cdre (Res) Teo Chee Hean) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the prices of Certificates of Entitlement (COEs) are determined by market forces of supply and demand. As the supply of COEs is fixed, the increase in COE prices simply reflects the higher demand for vehicles in the market.

    The strong demand for vehicles, and hence COEs, is a reflection of public

Column: 1199

confidence in the economy. So long as our economy continues to do well, we can expect demand for cars, trucks and buses to remain high. This means that COE prices will continue to face upward pressure from high market demand.

    The only way to moderate COE prices is to increase the supply of COEs. To do so, we must be able to allow higher vehicle growth without leading to widespread road congestion. The Ministry of Communications is therefore looking into various road-pricing measures, such as the whole-day ALS and Electronic Road Pricing, which will control congestion better to allow a higher level of vehicle ownership, and hence, more COEs to be released.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, one of the reasons for the increase in the car population is the availability of cheap finance. Will the Minister consider curbing cheap and liberal finance which finance companies are offering to motorcar purchasers?

    I have a related question to that. Will the Government also consider cutting down the practice of offering generous car loans to its officers?

     Cdre (Res) Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not sure what the Member is suggesting. But if he is suggesting that we increase the price of loan artificially, then I think that may impact unnecessarily on people who want to buy cars. We should let the market set the price for loans.

    With regard to his second question on whether or not the Government provides generous loans, I do not think the loan conditions of the Government for cars are generous. I think they are adequate.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Obviously, the Minister has not understood my question. The purpose of COE, as stated by the Government, is to curb or reduce congestion on our roads; in other words, to bring down the car population. Does he not agree with me that one of the reasons why there are so many people buying cars is the easy availability of cheap car loans? If the Government has a policy on car loans by the finance companies that you must

Column: 1200

provide upfront 70% or 80% cash to buy a car, I am sure the number of car purchasers will be very much less than today.

     Cdre (Res) Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, the purpose of the COE system and the Vehicle Quota System is to limit the growth in the vehicle population to a manageable level. Whether or not the financing aspect for COE ought to be manipulated in a way which makes the financing cost different from what the market sets is a separate issue from whether or not the car population can be controlled. I think the car population is being controlled satisfactorily by the system and there is no necessity to interfere with the financial market in order to cater to this particular requirement.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Can I say that if you do not control the financing aspect and more people are buying cars, the Government will get more revenue by issuing, in fact, more COEs? Am I not right?

     Cdre (Res) Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, the decision on whether or not individuals wish to bid for a COE at the prevailing prices is really up to them, and it is the decision of the individual and the upward pressures being provided by the generally good economic conditions that are much stronger than any of the measures that the Member has suggested.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): I would like to ask the Minister of State whether the Government will consider other forms of bidding for COEs since, as we all know now, the COE is very high. Are there other alternatives that we can consider for the bidding of COEs? For example, one method that is often suggested is the pay-as-you-bid system.

     Cdre (Res) Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, this question has been raised a number of times. The pay-as-you-bid system is in no way superior to the current system, which is the single strike price system. There is a good body of knowledge on this subject which has been developed by economists and the theory shows that the present

Column: 1201

bidding system is a fair system, and the price should not be affected, whether or not you use this bidding system or a pay-as-you-bid system. But we would be willing to accept any reasonable suggestion which Members may have to improve the system.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, whether the pay-as-you-bid system will be higher or lower compared to the present Dutch system has not been tested as yet. But could the Government consider putting it on trial for a few months just to see how it will work out? FEMALE CIVIL SERVANTS


    7. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Finance (a) if he will state the absolute number and percentage of female civil servants who are (i) single, (ii) married, (iii) divorced and (iv) widowed; (b) what would be the increase in dollar terms and as a percentage of the total payroll if female civil servants were awarded the same medical benefits as their male counterparts; and (c) what is the number of female civil servants with spouses also in the civil service.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau:

    The breakdown of women civil servants by marital status is as follows: 

             Status         Number      %



             Single         11,054     34.3

             Married        20,078     62.2

             Divorced          544      1.7

             Widowed           587      1.8

                            ______    _____

                            32,263    100.0

                            ======    =====


    If women civil servants were accorded the same medical benefits as their male counterparts, the estimated increase in medical subsidy is $8.1 million or about 0.4% of total payroll.

    There are about 940 women officers whose spouses are also in the Civil Service.
